Application.name: org.astrogrid/Starburst99

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: NAME
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: any identifier you want to assign to the model. You will find it in the header of each output file.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: ISF
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Name: CONTINUOUS STAR FORMATION (>0) OR FIXED MASS (<=0)
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: if this is a negative integer, star formation is instantaneous, otherwise it is continuous.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: TOMA
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Name: TOTAL STELLAR MASS [10^6 SOLAR MASSES] IF 'FIXED MASS' IS CHOSEN
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: this is the total stellar mass (spread out between the upper and lower cut-off masses). It is only used if an instantaneous burst is specified.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: SFR
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Name: SFR [SOLAR MASSES PER YEAR] IF 'CONT. SF' IS CHOSEN:
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: the star formation rate (only used for a continuous rate). The total accumulated mass is spread out between the upper and lower cut-off masses.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: ALPHA
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: IMF exponent. A power law is assumed.(2.35 = SALPETER):

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: UPMA
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: upper mass limit for the IMF.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: DOMA
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: lower mass limit for the IMF.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: SNCUT
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: stars with ZAMS masses of 8 M and higher form supernovae. This is the suggested standard value but can be modified if desired.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: BHCUT
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: stars with ZAMS masses of 120 M and lower form supernovae. An alternative scenario would be to let stars above a certain threshold form a black hole. For instance, BHCUT=40. results in SNe only from the mass range 40 to 8 M.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: IZ
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: 92-94 STD. MASS-LOSS: 11=0.001; 12=0.004; 13=0.008; 14=0.020; 15=0.040 92-94 HIGH MASS-LOSS: 21=0.001; 22=0.004; 23=0.008; 24=0.020; 25=0.040 24 -- this integer indicates the evolutionary tracks to be used. The choices are 11-15 or 21-25, where the former select one of five metallicities with the standard tracks, and the latter do the same for the high mass-loss tracks. Example: "23" selects 40% solar metallicity with the high mass loss tracks.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: IWIND
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: (0=MAEDER; 1=EMP.; 2=THEOR.; 3=ELSON; 4=UCL): [IWIND] 2 -- this selects the wind model to be used for the calculation of the wind power. The four models are discussed in ApJ, 401, 498 (1992) and in Smith et al. (2002). "2" is the suggested default parameter.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: TIME1
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: [1.E6 YEARS] the epoch of the onset of the star formation. In almost all cases you want this to be close to 0. It should not be exactly 0 for numerical reasons. 0.01 (i.e. 10e4 yr) is a good number.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: STEP
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: [1.e6 years] this is the timestep used for the calculations. It is a very important parameter. On the one hand, the computing time scales with STEP, so you want to avoid too high resolution, but on the other, short evolutionary phases can be missed. 0.1 (i.e. 10e5 yr) is a good value if you use full isochrone synthesis. If full isochrone synthesis is not used, 0.1 or larger is suggested only for tests --- be aware that WR or RSG numbers are no longer properly calculated for a STEP of 0.1 unless full isochrone synthesis is selected!

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: TMAX
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: [1.e6 YEARS]: the oldest age of the model.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: JMG
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Name: SMALL (=0) OR LARGE (=1) MASS GRID; ISOCHRONE ON LARGE GRID (=2) OR FULL ISOCHRONE (=3):
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: these are four options for the interpolation in mass. They are explained in the code. Shortly: 0 -- evolutionary synthesis with a mass resolution of 5 M (only recommended for tests); 1 -- same as 0, but with a resolution of 1 M. This method was used in Leitherer & Heckman (1995); 2 -- isochrone synthesis with a fixed mass resolution of 1 M; 3 -- isochrone synthesis with a variable mass grid. This is the fanciest method and is the recommended mode.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: LMIN
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: LMIN and LMAX are the indices of the evolutionary tracks, sorted by mass. Normally you do not want to mess with the variable and leave it at 0. However, if you want to track down some peculiarity of the output, you may want to compute the parameters for only one track. For instance, specifying 21,21 indicates that only a 100 M star should by used, and everything else is suppressed. The cross-ID's between index and mass are at the bottom of the input file. The example here refers to JMG=1 or 2. For JMG=0, you would have chosen 5,5. This does not apply to JMG=3 since the mass grid is variable and LMIN, LMAX are not used.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: LMAX
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: LMIN and LMAX are the indices of the evolutionary tracks, sorted by mass. Normally you do not want to mess with the variable and leave it at 0. However, if you want to track down some peculiarity of the output, you may want to compute the parameters for only one track. For instance, specifying 21,21 indicates that only a 100 M star should by used, and everything else is suppressed. The cross-ID's between index and mass are at the bottom of the input file. The example here refers to JMG=1 or 2. For JMG=0, you would have chosen 5,5. This does not apply to JMG=3 since the mass grid is variable and LMIN, LMAX are not used.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: TDEL
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: [1.e6YR] the file containing the output spectrum can be pretty big. This parameter controls the time step to print out the spectrum. This is independent of the time resolution -- only the print out is affected! 1 Myr is usually a good value but if you compute the starburst up to 100 Myr, you may prefer TDEL=5 Myr unless you have many Gb of disk space.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: IATMOS
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: 1=PLA,2=LEJ,3=LEJ+SCH,4=LEJ+HIL,5=PAU+HIL [IATMOS] 5 -- this is the choice of the model atmosphere. 1 is a bare-bone version with black bodies, good only for tests. 2 uses the Kurucz models as compiled by Lejeune for all stars. 3 uses Lejeune for stars with plane-parallel atmospheres and Schmutz for stars with strong winds. 4 uses Lejeune, but replaces the Schmutz by the Hillier atmospheres. 5 is like 4, except for the O atmospheres, for which we use the Pauldrach models. 5 is the recommended value.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: ILINE
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Name: METALLICITY OF THE UV LINE SPECTRUM:
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: 1=SOLAR, 2=LMC/SMC) [ILINE] 1 -- a switch for the choice of the UV spectral library. This switch applies to both the FUSE and the HST/IUE libraries. It is independent of the metallicity of the tracks/atmospheres. Normally one would use ILINE=1 with IZ=24 and ILINE=2 with IZ=22.

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: IVT
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: atmospheric parameters used for the spectral features in the near-IR. Detailed explanations are in the sp-feature subroutine. Defaults are 3,0, i.e. microturbulent velocities of 3 km/sec and solar abundance ratios for alpha-element/Fe

CmdLineParameterDefn.name: IRSG
CmdLineParameterDefn.agpd:UI_Description: atmospheric parameters used for the spectral features in the near-IR. Detailed explanations are in the sp-feature subroutine. Defaults are 3,0, i.e. microturbulent velocities of 3 km/sec and solar abundance ratios for alpha-element/Fe
